Digitised: Gallica BnF
Notes: First (princeps) edition published anonymously in Geneva by Barrillot & Fils, overseen cautiously by Montesquieu amid censorship concerns.
Parisian reprint published in January 1749 under the address: "In Geneva, at Barillot fils" with corrections list (errata)

Additional corrections are also among the errata printed in another in-4° edition of 1749 which probably dates from March and bears the false address: "A Leiden, Chez les Libraires associés" (this is a Lyon edition printed by Aimé Delaroche for Pierre and Benoît Duplain)

Digitised: Part 1–2. Internet Archive
Notes: Montesquieu sent list of corrections to Geneva. Barrillot had been authorised by Vernet to prepare two reprints of the 1748 edition, one in two volumes in-4°, the other in three volumes in-8°

Tome 2 Internet Archive
Notes: Montesquieu sent list of corrections to Geneva. Barrillot had been authorised by Vernet to prepare two reprints of the 1748 edition, one in two volumes in-4°, the other in three volumes in-8°

Parisian bookseller-printer Pierre-Michel Huart prints edition, two volumes in-4°, which includes a Table of contents and a map; it appeared in May 1749, under the false address: "In Geneva, at Barrillot et fils".

Parisian bookseller-printer Pierre-Michel Huart prints edition, two volumes in-4°, which includes a Table of contents and a map; it appeared in May 1749, under the false address: "In Geneva, at Barrillot et fils".
London bookseller-printer John Nourse, who will publish in May or June a two-volume edition in-8°, which bear Barrillot's address.
Two volumes in-4°, which is based on the Barrillot in-8° edition of 1749 and bears on the title page the address: "À Amsterdam, La Compagnie".

Tome 2. Internet Archive
Tome 3. Internet Archive
Notes: Printers seem to have had access to the list of corrections, which resulted in a reprint of the Huart edition of 1749 in three volumes in-8° published in Amsterdam by Chatelain.
An in-8° edition in three volumes published under the address of Barillot; it is probably a new Parisian reprint published by Durand.

Notes: The Scottish edition, in two volumes in-8°, dated 1750, will be published in November 1749, David Hume and a certain Mr. Alexandre having played the role of intermediaries between Montesquieu and the Hamilton publishing house and Balfour of Edinburgh.

Digitised:
Tome 2 Google Books
Tome 3 Internet Archive
Notes: New corrections to Huart for a 1750 edition in three volumes in-12 (published under the false address of Barrillot or Nourse). Montesquieu alludes to this in a letter dated April 8, 1750 addressed to Grosley: the most exact edition is the last edition printed in 3 vols. in-12, in Paris, at Huart, bookseller, rue Saint-Jacques, near Fontaine Saint-Séverin".

Notes: Montesquieu, carrying out a more general revision to take into account the religious criticism that the work had attracted. This work was interrupted by his death in 1755 and the revised edition, prepared by third parties, did not appear until 1757. Published in Paris by Huart and Moreau (under the address "London, chez Nourse") in four volumes in-12.
